sn3.19:1.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo divā divassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn3.19:1.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha in the middle of the day, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

sn3.19:1.3.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, āgacchasi divā divassā”ti?
sn3.19:1.3.eng: “So, great king, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

sn3.19:2.1.eng: “Sir, here in Sāvatthī a financier householder has passed away.

sn3.19:2.2.pli: Tamahaṃ aputtakaṃ sāpateyyaṃ rājantepuraṃ atiharitvā āgacchāmi.
sn3.19:2.2.eng: Since he died childless, I have come after transferring his fortune to the royal compound.
sn3.19:2.2.comm: This accords with Arthaśāstra 3.5.28, “A king should take property for which there is no heir”.

sn3.19:2.3.pli: Asīti, bhante, satasahassāni hiraññasseva, ko pana vādo rūpiyassa.
sn3.19:2.3.eng: There was eight million in gold coin, not to mention the silver coin.

sn3.19:2.4.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhante, seṭṭhissa gahapatissa evarūpo bhattabhogo ahosi—
sn3.19:2.4.eng: And yet that financier ate meals of

sn3.19:2.5.eng: rough gruel with false black pepper.

sn3.19:2.7.comm: Hemp (sāṇa) made a rough  cloth. It was not known as an intoxicant.

sn3.19:2.8.eng: He traveled around in a vehicle that was

sn3.19:2.9.eng: a dilapidated little cart, holding a leaf as parasol.”
sn3.19:2.9.comm: Compare the splendid chariot of the brahmin Jānussoṇi (SN 45.4:1.3).

sn3.19:3.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!

sn3.19:3.2.pli: Asappuriso kho, mahārāja, uḷāre bhoge labhitvā nevattānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti, na mātāpitaro sukheti pīṇeti, na puttadāraṃ sukheti pīṇeti, na dāsakammakaraporise sukheti pīṇeti, na mittāmacce sukheti pīṇeti, na samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
sn3.19:3.2.eng: When an untrue person has acquired notable wealth they don’t make themselves happy and pleased. Nor do they make their mother and father, partners and children, bondservants, workers, and staff, and friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they don’t establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
sn3.19:3.2.comm: The proper use of wealth includes enjoying it oneself as well as helping others.

sn3.19:3.3.pli: Tassa te bhoge evaṃ sammā aparibhuñjiyamāne rājāno vā haranti corā vā haranti aggi vā ḍahati udakaṃ vā vahati appiyā vā dāyādā haranti.
sn3.19:3.3.eng: Because they haven’t made proper use of that wealth, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it.

sn3.19:3.4.pli: Evaṃsa te, mahārāja, bhogā sammā aparibhuñjiyamānā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, no paribhogaṃ.
sn3.19:3.4.eng: Since that wealth is not properly utilized, it’s wasted, not used.

sn3.19:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, amanussaṭṭhāne pokkharaṇī acchodakā sītodakā sātodakā setodakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā.
sn3.19:4.1.eng: Suppose there was a lotus pond in an uninhabited region with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful.

sn3.19:4.2.pli: Taṃ jano neva hareyya na piveyya na nahāyeyya na yathāpaccayaṃ vā kareyya.
sn3.19:4.2.eng: But people don’t collect it or drink it or bathe in it or use it for any purpose.

sn3.19:4.3.pli: Evañhi taṃ, mahārāja, udakaṃ sammā aparibhuñjiyamānaṃ parikkhayaṃ gaccheyya, no paribhogaṃ.
sn3.19:4.3.eng: Since that water is not properly utilized, it’s wasted, not used.

sn3.19:4.4.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, asappuriso uḷāre bhoge labhitvā nevattānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti, na mātāpitaro sukheti pīṇeti, na puttadāraṃ sukheti pīṇeti, na dāsakammakaraporise sukheti pīṇeti, na mittāmacce sukheti pīṇeti, na samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
sn3.19:4.4.eng: In the same way, when an untrue person has acquired notable wealth …

sn3.19:4.5.pli: Tassa te bhoge evaṃ sammā aparibhuñjiyamāne rājāno vā haranti, corā vā haranti, aggi vā ḍahati, udakaṃ vā vahati, appiyā vā dāyādā haranti.

sn3.19:4.6.pli: Evaṃsa te, mahārāja, bhogā sammā aparibhuñjiyamānā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, no paribhogaṃ.

sn3.19:5.1.pli: Sappuriso ca kho, mahārāja, uḷāre bhoge labhitvā attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti, mātāpitaro sukheti pīṇeti, puttadāraṃ sukheti pīṇeti, dāsakammakaraporise sukheti pīṇeti, mittāmacce sukheti pīṇeti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
sn3.19:5.1.eng: When a true person has acquired notable wealth they make themselves happy and pleased. And they make their mother and father, partners and children, bondservants, workers, and staff, and friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.

sn3.19:5.2.pli: Tassa te bhoge evaṃ sammā paribhuñjiyamāne neva rājāno haranti, na corā haranti, na aggi ḍahati, na udakaṃ vahati, na appiyā dāyādā haranti.
sn3.19:5.2.eng: Because they make proper use of that wealth, rulers or bandits don’t take it, fire doesn’t consume it, flood doesn’t sweep it away, and unloved heirs don’t take it.

sn3.19:5.3.pli: Evaṃsa te, mahārāja, bhogā sammā paribhuñjiyamānā paribhogaṃ gacchanti, no parikkhayaṃ.
sn3.19:5.3.eng: Since that wealth is properly utilized, it’s used, not wasted.

sn3.19:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre pokkharaṇī acchodakā sītodakā sātodakā setodakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā.
sn3.19:6.1.eng: Suppose there was a lotus pond not far from a town or village with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful.

sn3.19:6.2.pli: Tañca udakaṃ jano hareyyapi piveyyapi nahāyeyyapi yathāpaccayampi kareyya.
sn3.19:6.2.eng: And people collected it and drank it and bathed in it and used it for their own purpose.

sn3.19:6.3.pli: Evañhi taṃ, mahārāja, udakaṃ sammā paribhuñjiyamānaṃ paribhogaṃ gaccheyya, no parikkhayaṃ.
sn3.19:6.3.eng: Since that water is properly utilized, it’s used, not wasted.

sn3.19:6.4.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, sappuriso uḷāre bhoge labhitvā attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti, mātāpitaro sukheti pīṇeti, puttadāraṃ sukheti pīṇeti, dāsakammakaraporise sukheti pīṇeti, mittāmacce sukheti pīṇeti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
sn3.19:6.4.eng: In the same way, when a true person has acquired notable wealth …

sn3.19:6.5.pli: Tassa te bhoge evaṃ sammā paribhuñjiyamāne neva rājāno haranti, na corā haranti, na aggi ḍahati, na udakaṃ vahati, na appiyā dāyādā haranti.

sn3.19:6.6.pli: Evaṃsa te, mahārāja, bhogā sammā paribhuñjiyamānā paribhogaṃ gacchanti, no parikkhayan”ti.

sn3.19:7.1.eng: As cool water in an uninhabited region

sn3.19:7.3.eng: so too when a reprobate acquires wealth,

sn3.19:7.4.eng: they neither use it themselves nor give it away.

sn3.19:8.1.eng: When the attentive and sensible acquire wealth,

sn3.19:8.3.eng: That boss, having supported the family unit,
sn3.19:8.3.comm: Nisabha means “bull” and “chief”, both of which are covered by “boss”.

sn3.19:8.4.eng: blameless, goes to a heavenly place.”

sn3.2:1.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.2:1.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha,

sn3.2:1.3.pli: “kati nu kho, bhante, purisassa dhammā ajjhattaṃ uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāyā”ti?
sn3.2:1.3.eng: “Sir, how many things arise inside a person for their harm, suffering, and discomfort?”
sn3.2:1.3.comm: While we cannot trace Pasenadi’s progress with confidence, we can see that here he has gone from questioning the Buddha’s awakening to learning fundamentals of Buddhist psychology.

sn3.2:2.1.pli: “Tayo kho, mahārāja, purisassa dhammā ajjhattaṃ uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.
sn3.2:2.1.eng: “Great king, three things arise inside a person for their harm, suffering, and discomfort.

sn3.2:2.3.pli: Lobho kho, mahārāja, purisassa dhammo ajjhattaṃ uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.

sn3.2:2.4.pli: Doso kho, mahārāja, purisassa dhammo ajjhattaṃ uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.

sn3.2:2.5.pli: Moho kho, mahārāja, purisassa dhammo ajjhattaṃ uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.

sn3.2:2.6.pli: Ime kho, mahārāja, tayo purisassa dhammā ajjhattaṃ uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāyā”ti.
sn3.2:2.6.eng: These three things arise inside a person for their harm, suffering, and discomfort.”

sn3.2:2.7.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.2:3.3.eng: they harm a person of wicked heart,

sn3.2:3.4.eng: as a bamboo is destroyed by its own fruit.”
sn3.2:3.4.comm: Tacasāra (Sanskrit tvaksāra) is “that which has hardwood for its skin”, namely the bamboo (see SN 6.12:2.2).

sn3.20:1.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo divā divassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn3.20:1.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha in the middle of the day … The Buddha said to him,

sn3.20:1.2.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, āgacchasi divā divassā”ti?
sn3.20:1.2.eng: “So, great king, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

sn3.20:2.1.eng: “Sir, here in Sāvatthī a financier householder has passed away.

sn3.20:2.2.pli: Tamahaṃ aputtakaṃ sāpateyyaṃ rājantepuraṃ atiharitvā āgacchāmi.
sn3.20:2.2.eng: Since he died childless, I have come after transferring his fortune to the royal compound.

sn3.20:2.3.pli: Sataṃ, bhante, satasahassāni hiraññasseva, ko pana vādo rūpiyassa.
sn3.20:2.3.eng: There was ten million in gold coin, not to mention the silver coin.

sn3.20:2.4.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhante, seṭṭhissa gahapatissa evarūpo bhattabhogo ahosi—
sn3.20:2.4.eng: And yet that financier ate meals of

sn3.20:2.5.eng: rough gruel with false black pepper.

sn3.20:2.8.eng: He traveled around in a vehicle that was

sn3.20:2.9.eng: a dilapidated little cart, holding a leaf as parasol.”

sn3.20:3.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!

sn3.20:3.2.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati taggarasikhiṃ nāma paccekasambuddhaṃ piṇḍapātena paṭipādesi.
sn3.20:3.2.eng: Once upon a time, great king, that financier householder provided almsfood on behalf of an Independent Buddha named Tagarasikhī.
sn3.20:3.2.comm: The concept of the paccekabuddha allows that there were awakened sages in the long periods of time when there is no sambuddha such as Gotama. Both are Buddhas in the sense of being awakened, but they differ in their relation to others. It is sometimes said that they do not teach, but the tradition attributes to them a number of sayings (notably Snp 1.3). They are sometimes said to be “solitary”, but in MN 116, 500 dwell on the same hill, while pacceka Brahmās appear in pairs (SN 6.6:1.3). Compare Bu NP 9:1.36.1, where “independent” funds are set up for “independent” robes (rather than combining them); the same idea occurs at AN 11.16:11.2. Likewise, SN 1.37:1.7 speaks of “independent” verses. Thus the burden of sense in the Pali is that pacceka means “independent’, which here has the sense of not forming a fourfold community, but simply living and practicing independently.

sn3.20:3.3.eng: He instructed: ‘Give alms to that ascetic,’ before getting up from his seat and leaving.
sn3.20:3.3.comm: He did not give with his own hands.

sn3.20:3.4.pli: Datvā ca pana pacchā vippaṭisārī ahosi:
sn3.20:3.4.eng: But after giving he regretted it:

sn3.20:3.5.pli: ‘varametaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ dāsā vā kammakarā vā bhuñjeyyun’ti.
sn3.20:3.5.eng: ‘It would have been better to feed the bondservants or workers with that almsfood.’
sn3.20:3.5.comm: Giving to workers is obviously good, but it is not good to regret one’s generosity.

sn3.20:3.6.pli: Bhātu ca pana ekaputtakaṃ sāpateyyassa kāraṇā jīvitā voropesi.
sn3.20:3.6.eng: What’s more, he murdered his brother’s only child for the sake of his fortune.

sn3.20:4.1.pli: Yaṃ kho so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati taggarasikhiṃ paccekasambuddhaṃ piṇḍapātena paṭipādesi, tassa kammassa vipākena sattakkhattuṃ sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajji.
sn3.20:4.1.eng: Because that financier provided Tagarasikhī with almsfood, as a result of that deed he was reborn seven times in a good place, a heavenly realm.
sn3.20:4.1.comm: This sequence shows the complexity of deeds and their results.

sn3.20:4.2.pli: Tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena imissāyeva sāvatthiyā sattakkhattuṃ seṭṭhittaṃ kāresi.
sn3.20:4.2.eng: And as a residual result of that same deed he held the position of financier seven times right here in Sāvatthī.

sn3.20:4.3.pli: Yaṃ kho so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati datvā pacchā vippaṭisārī ahosi:
sn3.20:4.3.eng: But because that financier regretted giving alms,

sn3.20:4.4.pli: ‘varametaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ dāsā vā kammakarā vā bhuñjeyyun’ti, tassa kammassa vipākena nāssuḷārāya bhattabhogāya cittaṃ namati, nāssuḷārāya vatthabhogāya cittaṃ namati, nāssuḷārāya yānabhogāya cittaṃ namati, nāssuḷārānaṃ pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ bhogāya cittaṃ namati.
sn3.20:4.4.eng: as a result of that deed his mind didn’t tend to enjoy nice food, clothes, vehicles, or the five refined kinds of sensual stimulation.
sn3.20:4.4.comm: The regret did not cancel out the good deed, but it took the shine off it.

sn3.20:4.5.pli: Yaṃ kho so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati bhātu ca pana ekaputtakaṃ sāpateyyassa kāraṇā jīvitā voropesi, tassa kammassa vipākena bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni bahūni vassasatasahassāni niraye paccittha.
sn3.20:4.5.eng: And because that financier murdered his brother’s only child for the sake of his fortune, as a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, for many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years.
sn3.20:4.5.comm: The results are proportionate to the deeds.

sn3.20:4.6.pli: Tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena idaṃ sattamaṃ aputtakaṃ sāpateyyaṃ rājakosaṃ paveseti.
sn3.20:4.6.eng: And as a residual result of that same deed, he is childless for the seventh time, his fortune ending up in the royal treasury.
sn3.20:4.6.comm: Rebirth in hell was for the murder, while childlessness is because he tried to usurp the inheritance.

sn3.20:4.7.pli: Tassa kho, mahārāja, seṭṭhissa gahapatissa purāṇañca puññaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ, navañca puññaṃ anupacitaṃ.
sn3.20:4.7.eng: Now the old merit of that financier has been used up, and he hasn’t accumulated new merit.

sn3.20:4.8.pli: Ajja pana, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati mahāroruve niraye paccatī”ti.
sn3.20:4.8.eng: Today, great king, that financier burns in the Great Hell of Screams.”

sn3.20:4.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante, seṭṭhi gahapati mahāroruvaṃ nirayaṃ upapanno”ti.
sn3.20:4.9.eng: “Really, sir, that financier has been reborn in the Great Hell of Screams?”

sn3.20:4.10.pli: “Evaṃ, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati mahāroruvaṃ nirayaṃ upapanno”ti.

sn3.20:4.11.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.20:5.2.eng: or whatever other possessions there are;

sn3.20:5.4.eng: and those dependent for their livelihood:

sn3.20:6.1.eng: you must go on without taking these;

sn3.20:6.2.eng: all of them are left behind.

sn3.20:7.1.eng: that’s what you can call your own.

sn3.20:7.2.eng: That’s what you take when you go.

sn3.20:7.4.eng: like a shadow that never leaves.

sn3.20:8.1.eng: That’s why you should do good,

sn3.20:8.3.eng: The good deeds of sentient beings

sn3.20:8.4.eng: support them in the next world.”

sn3.21:1.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn3.21:1.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn3.21:1.3.eng: “Great king, these four individuals are found in the world.

sn3.21:1.8.eng: and the light bound for light.

sn3.21:2.1.eng: And how is an individual dark and bound for darkness?

sn3.21:2.2.pli: Idha, mahārāja, ekacco puggalo nīce kule paccājāto hoti, caṇḍālakule vā venakule vā nesādakule vā rathakārakule vā pukkusakule vā dalidde appannapānabhojane kasiravuttike, yattha kasirena ghāsacchādo labbhati.
sn3.21:2.2.eng: It’s when an individual is reborn in a low family—a family of corpse-workers, bamboo-workers, hunters, chariot-makers, or scavengers—poor, with little to eat or drink, where life is tough, and food and shelter are hard to find.
sn3.21:2.2.comm: Caṇḍālas (“corpse-workers”) are frequently depicted as the lowest of untouchables as seen by Brahmins. However, the usual rendering of “outcast” is unsatisfactory, as all the groups here are defined positively by their occupation, and moreover some, such as the scavengers, would also have been untouchable. The Pali commentaries equate the caṇḍāla with the chavaka (or chapaka) of Bu Sk 69:1.12.1, a “corpse disposer” (chavachaḍḍakacaṇḍālā; see also chavakacaṇḍālo at Mil 5.4.7:2.4). They were known for their “bone-washing” ceremony (DN 1:1.13.2, AN 10.107:1.1). This agrees with Rāmāyana 1.58.10, which describes a caṇḍāla as dark-complexioned, dirty, with disheveled hair, his body smeared with graveyard ash. Mahāvaṁsa 10.91–94 tells how King Paṇḍukābhaya employed caṇḍālas for cleaning streets and toilets, bearing the dead, and watching over cemeteries, with their village adjoining the cemetery. My grandfather was a corpse-worker, so in another world it might have been my inheritance.

sn3.21:2.3.pli: So ca hoti dubbaṇṇo duddasiko okoṭimako bavhābādho kāṇo vā kuṇī vā khañjo vā pakkhahato vā, na lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
sn3.21:2.3.eng: And they’re ugly, unsightly, deformed, sickly—one-eyed, crippled, lame, or half-paralyzed. They don’t get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; or bed, house, and lighting.

sn3.21:2.4.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
sn3.21:2.4.eng: And they do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn3.21:2.5.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
sn3.21:2.5.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn3.21:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso andhakārā vā andhakāraṃ gaccheyya, tamā vā tamaṃ gaccheyya, lohitamalā vā lohitamalaṃ gaccheyya.
sn3.21:3.1.eng: This individual is like someone who goes from darkness to darkness, from blackness to blackness, from bloodstain to bloodstain.
sn3.21:3.1.comm: Note the rare term lohitamala, “bloodstain”.

sn3.21:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, puggalo tamotamaparāyano hoti.
sn3.21:3.3.eng: That’s how an individual is dark and bound for darkness.

sn3.21:4.1.eng: And how is an individual dark and bound for light?

sn3.21:4.2.pli: Idha, mahārāja, ekacco puggalo nīce kule paccājāto hoti, caṇḍālakule vā venakule vā nesādakule vā rathakārakule vā pukkusakule vā dalidde appannapānabhojane kasiravuttike, yattha kasirena ghāsacchādo labbhati.
sn3.21:4.2.eng: It’s when an individual is reborn in a low family—a family of corpse-workers, bamboo-workers, hunters, chariot-makers, or scavengers—poor, with little to eat or drink, where life is tough, and food and shelter are hard to find.

sn3.21:4.3.pli: So ca kho hoti dubbaṇṇo duddasiko okoṭimako bavhābādho, kāṇo vā kuṇī vā khañjo vā pakkhahato vā, na lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
sn3.21:4.3.eng: And they’re ugly, unsightly, deformed, sickly—one-eyed, crippled, lame, or half-paralyzed. They don’t get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; or bed, house, and lighting.

sn3.21:4.4.pli: So kāyena sucaritaṃ carati, vācāya sucaritaṃ carati, manasā sucaritaṃ carati.
sn3.21:4.4.eng: But they do good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn3.21:4.5.pli: So kāyena sucaritaṃ caritvā vācāya sucaritaṃ caritvā manasā sucaritaṃ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
sn3.21:4.5.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn3.21:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso pathaviyā vā pallaṅkaṃ āroheyya, pallaṅkā vā assapiṭṭhiṃ āroheyya, assapiṭṭhiyā vā hatthikkhandhaṃ āroheyya, hatthikkhandhā vā pāsādaṃ āroheyya.
sn3.21:5.1.eng: This individual is like someone who ascends from the ground to a couch; from a couch to horseback; from horseback to an elephant; and from an elephant to a stilt longhouse.

sn3.21:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, puggalo tamojotiparāyano hoti.
sn3.21:5.3.eng: That’s how an individual is dark and bound for light.

sn3.21:6.1.eng: And how is an individual light and bound for darkness?

sn3.21:6.2.pli: Idha, mahārāja, ekacco puggalo ucce kule paccājāto hoti, khattiyamahāsālakule vā brāhmaṇamahāsālakule vā gahapatimahāsālakule vā, aḍḍhe mahaddhane mahābhoge pahūtajātarūparajate pahūtavittūpakaraṇe pahūtadhanadhaññe.
sn3.21:6.2.eng: It’s when an individual is reborn in an eminent family—a well-to-do family of aristocrats, brahmins, or householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain.

sn3.21:6.3.pli: So ca hoti abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko, paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato, lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
sn3.21:6.3.eng: And they’re attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. They get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

sn3.21:6.4.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
sn3.21:6.4.eng: But they do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn3.21:6.5.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
sn3.21:6.5.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

sn3.21:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso pāsādā vā hatthikkhandhaṃ oroheyya, hatthikkhandhā vā assapiṭṭhiṃ oroheyya, assapiṭṭhiyā vā pallaṅkaṃ oroheyya, pallaṅkā vā pathaviṃ oroheyya, pathaviyā vā andhakāraṃ paviseyya.
sn3.21:7.1.eng: This individual is like someone who descends from a stilt longhouse to an elephant; from an elephant to horseback; from horseback to a couch; and from a couch to the ground; and from the ground they enter darkness.
sn3.21:7.1.comm: The last phrase is curious. It doesn’t mirror the positive version of the simile, and it’s not clear exactly what it means. Of course it can be interpreted spiritually, but it’s a simile, the point is that it is describing something physical. Bodhi interprets it as “underground darkness”, but he misses the change in verb from “descend” to “enter”; and anyway, the text doesn’t say “underground”. Commentary is silent.

sn3.21:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, puggalo jotitamaparāyano hoti.
sn3.21:7.3.eng: That’s how an individual is light and bound for darkness.

sn3.21:8.1.eng: And how is an individual light and bound for light?

sn3.21:8.2.pli: Idha, mahārāja, ekacco puggalo ucce kule paccājāto hoti, khattiyamahāsālakule vā brāhmaṇamahāsālakule vā gahapatimahāsālakule vā, aḍḍhe mahaddhane mahābhoge pahūtajātarūparajate pahūtavittūpakaraṇe pahūtadhanadhaññe.
sn3.21:8.2.eng: It’s when an individual is reborn in an eminent family—a well-to-do family of aristocrats, brahmins, or householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain.

sn3.21:8.3.pli: So ca hoti abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko, paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato, lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
sn3.21:8.3.eng: And they’re attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. They get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

sn3.21:8.4.pli: So kāyena sucaritaṃ carati, vācāya sucaritaṃ carati, manasā sucaritaṃ carati.
sn3.21:8.4.eng: And they do good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn3.21:8.5.pli: So kāyena sucaritaṃ caritvā vācāya sucaritaṃ caritvā manasā sucaritaṃ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
sn3.21:8.5.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn3.21:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso pallaṅkā vā pallaṅkaṃ saṅkameyya, assapiṭṭhiyā vā assapiṭṭhiṃ saṅkameyya, hatthikkhandhā vā hatthikkhandhaṃ saṅkameyya, pāsādā vā pāsādaṃ saṅkameyya.
sn3.21:9.1.eng: This individual is like someone who shifts from one couch to another; from the back of one horse to another; from one elephant to another; or from one stilt longhouse to another.

sn3.21:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, puggalo jotijotiparāyano hoti.
sn3.21:9.3.eng: That’s how an individual is light and bound for light.

sn3.21:9.4.pli: Ime kho, mahārāja, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
sn3.21:9.4.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.”

sn3.21:9.5.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.21:10.4.eng: they lack regard, they have wrong view.

sn3.21:12.3.eng: O king, ruler of the people:

sn3.21:12.5.eng: they fall into the terrible hell—

sn3.21:12.6.eng: from darkness they’re bound for darkness.

sn3.21:13.1.eng: O king, some people are poor,

sn3.21:13.3.eng: They give with best of intentions,

sn3.21:14.1.eng: They rise for and bow to

sn3.21:15.1.eng: they don’t prevent others from giving

sn3.21:15.3.eng: O king, ruler of the people:

sn3.21:15.5.eng: they go to the Third Heaven—
sn3.21:15.5.comm: The tidiva was the realm of Indra/Sakka (DN 21:1.12.22, DN 30:2.27.12, Thag 10.1:8.4), as it was from the time of the Vedas (Rig Veda 9.113.9, Atharva Veda 10.9.5, 17.1.10). In Buddhist cosmology, this agrees with the fact that Sakka’s realm is the third of the heavens (after the earth gods and the four great kings). Thus the Third Heaven is the heaven of the Thirty-Three. Both ideas spring from an old association of Indra, or divinity generally, with the number three. Agni Purāṇa lists tridiva as a synonym for “heaven”, as does Amarakośa 1.1.11. Kṣīrasvāmin clarifies that three here means “third”, while also adding that some connect it with the Brahmā realm (Amarakośodghāṭana 1.1.6; see SN 7.18:4.2).

sn3.21:15.6.eng: from darkness they’re bound for light.

sn3.21:16.4.eng: they lack regard, they have wrong view.
